article.description:
Antawn Jamison took things personally
after Donnell Harvey gave him fits in their previous meeting, and
he set the tone early.
article.headline: Jamison scores 15 of his 34 points in first quarter
article.linkText: Jamison gets going early to help Warriors bury Nuggets
article.story:
OAKLAND, Calif. (AP) -- Antawn Jamison took things personally after Donnell Harvey gave him fits in their previous meeting, and he set the tone early.
Antawn Jamison
Forward
Golden State Warriors
Profile
2002-2003 SEASON STATISTICS
GM PPG RPG APG FG% FT%
17 24.0 6.5 1.6 .441 .807
Jamison scored 15 of his 34 points in the first quarter as the Golden State Warriors extended their longest winning streak in more than a year to three games with a 110-89 victory over the Denver Nuggets on Tuesday night. Playing before a season-low crowd of 10,007, Troy Murphy added 16 points -- making all 12 of his free throws -- as Golden State put together its first three-game victory streak since last Nov. 9-12. ''In the first game, Donnell Harvey had me frustrated and took me out of my rhythm,'' said Jamison of his 11-point effort on 3-for-14 shooting against the Nuggets last Friday. ''This time I wanted to match his intensity and get it going,'' said Jamison. ''I wanted to deliver the first blow.'' Jamison was 5-for-8 from the field and 5-for-6 from the foul line as he helped the Warriors open a big lead. ''We felt the first 12 minutes were more important than the final 12 minutes,'' said Warriors' coach Eric Musselman. ''We felt we had to set the tempo and establish our half-court sets. When a guy starts scoring we keep feeding him the ball.'' Harvey scored a season-high 16 points for the Nuggets, who dropped their third in a row following a three-game winning streak. Juwan Howard added 14. ''Jamison came out with a great shooting night,'' said Harvey, who suffered a left shin contusion and is day-to-day. ''He got a couple of baskets to fall for him early and that was big.'' Golden State became just the second team to reach 100 points against Denver this season. The Atlanta Hawks scored 103 on Nov. 5. ''It's unacceptable to continue to start they way we do,'' Nuggets coach Jeff Bzdelik said. ''I'm disappointed. There might have to be some changes here. You can't bury yourself and expect to get back in it.'' Denver's James Posey was out of the starting lineup for the first time this season, leaving center Mark Blount as the only member of the Nuggets to start all 17 games. Golden State has used the same lineup in all 18 games. ''Jamison was hot,'' said Posey. ''They stayed aggressive from the last game and they got off to a good start.'' The Warriors held their ninth consecutive opponent to less than 100 points, their longest streak since an 11-game stretch between March 17 and April 5, 1999. ''When we look back and evaluate the stats, it's been our defense,'' said Musselman. ''We've been able to add things defensively.'' The Nuggets, who have yet to score more than 96 points in a game, pulled to 68-55 when Howard hit a short jumper with 4:33 left in the third quarter. Golden State rallied to take an 82-63 advantage into the final period. The Warriors sprinted to the early lead behind the torrid shooting of Jamison. The 34 first-quarter points were the most by the Warriors this season, as was Jamison's production. ''It's starting to click in,'' said Jamison. ''We're starting to get some chemistry.'' Denver, the worst shooting team in the NBA, mustered just six field goals in 27 shots and scored a Warriors' opponent-low of 16 in the opening period. The Warriors led by as many as 23 points in building a 55-37 halftime lead. Game notes
Denver placed forward Chris Andersen on the injured list with a fractured right thumb and activated swingman Vincent Yarbrough, who made his NBA debut. ... The Nuggets used their 12th different starting lineup. ... Jamison, who scored 30 or more for the fifth time, has started 182 consecutive games -- the most by a Warrior since Chris Mullin started 185 between 1988 and 1990. ... The 37 halftime points by Denver were a Warriors' opponent season-low. ... Golden State has shot 30 or more free throws in its last nine games after doing so once in its first nine. ... The Warriors made a season-high 40 free throws.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
